comments.text:
+Patrycja Rodzonek Oficjalnie obwieszczam że nie mam problemu z tym, że

ktoś napisze, że jest inaczej?

+Szymon Czarny jak się komuś wytyka, że "pewnie zasponsorowane" to jednak

comments.author: Patrycja Rodzonek

comments.text:
+hivess89 Nie wiem jak to działa, dlatego to napisałem :I Fakt, że jeszcze 
nie zdradził się ze swoim sponsoringiem nie wyklucza go. Poza tym 
przyjacielu mylisz się, ostatni wyjazd do Japonii został zorganizowany ze 
współpracą z Huawei, dlatego też powstał konkurs związany z ich telefonem, 
a ponadto wszystkie zdjęcia na facebooku były robione tym telefonem i 
zawierały tag, który nas o tym informował. Za pierwszym razem też 
zareklamował kilka marek tudzież produktów. 

Wyjazdy te nie koniecznie musiały być inicjatywą ze strony ww. marek, ale 
warunkiem ustalonym przez Krzysztofa, który wycenił swój wizerunek oraz sam 
fakt reklamowania danego produktu. Gdzie napisałem, że mu zazdroszczę albo 
mam z tym problem?
comments.author: Szymon Czarny

comments.text:
+Szymon Czarny Kolega chyba nie wie co to są materiały sponsorowane :) 
Wyprawy z Orange były sponsorowane - były oznaczone itp. Oskarżasz pana 
Gonciarza o łamanie prawa? Materiał sponsorowany musi być oznaczony. 
Zresztą - co on tu niby reklamuje? Broń na misie polarne? A w Japonii? Co 
niby reklamował? Chyba tylko na jeden odcinek miał tam umowę z Pepsi czy z 
czymś, a na pozostałe kilkadziesiąt nic.

Serio, ja rozumiem zazdrość, ale ogarnijcie się z tym sponsorowaniem 
wszędzie. Niektórzy po prostu dobrze zarabiają :X
comments.author: hivess89

captions.text: Hi! I'm in a very special place today.

It is just after midnight,
but the Sun is still up.

We are on the Spitsbergen island, which
is a part of the Svalbard archipelago.

It's far in the North, so I'm
taking part in a Polar expedition.

This island is inhabited by about 2000 people
and even higher number of polar bears.

We are surrounded by glaciers, rock
formations and there are absolutely no trees.

Right now we are close to the airport,
near Longyearbyen town.
It is the only proper town on the island.

You need to be well equipped and prepared
 to get outside of the city.

It is required to have
a gun or a guide

with a riffle for protection
against polar bears.

Bears can come close to campings and some
of them may not be scared of people.

A hungry bear can eat your food
supplies, if you are lucky.
Worst case: it can kill you.
Behind me there is a shooting range,

where we will learn how to use a riffle 
in case of emergency.

Behind me you can see
the Global Seed Vault,

where food crops are preserved
for future generations.

This place has been chosen for storage,
because of its stable climate conditions.

It all looks like a scenery from a sci-fi
movie, like the beginning of the 'Prometeus':

apocalyptic, foreign, but
still very interesting.

All of that makes it a
unique tourist destination.

So far I only showed and
mentioned the inhabited area,

but we will soon
move into the real wild.

I hope to show you unreal,
remote parts of it.
Svalbard is the Norwegian autonomy.

Norwegian is the most spoken language
here with Russian as the second.

Svalbard is not within the
Schengen zone

- it is neutral, so anyone can
come and settle down here.

The largest minority on the
island comes from Thailand

and this is just one of the things
you can find surprising here.

I'm just about to participate
in a silly ritual for tourists.

I will dive in the cold sea
to receive a certificate....
I just got my certificate.

The truth is, I should
get something better.

I just had spent more than five
minutes in that ice-cold water
cause I lost my glasses while diving.

I've never been in a place like this
before and it's a big challenge.

Not only from personal  but also from 
a YouTube film maker point of view.

Mobile and network connections
are limited to inhabited areas,

which will make it difficult
to upload the videos, but still

I hope that most of material
will be published from here.

You can trust me, it is not that easy to
produce anything like that in this place.

Tomorrow the expedition heads to Pyramiden,
the abandoned soviet coal mining city.

I welcome you to follow us
by watching videos on my channel.
Its nearly 1AM, time to sleep,

but first I want to show you
reindeer antlers and skulls.

Down there we have 
fragments of a whale spine.

It's all remaining of the
spectacular local wildlife.
